Award.AwardTitle: Bandgap-Tunable Graphene Nanoribbons for High Speed, Ultra-Wide-Band Photodetectors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices (EPMD) Program in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) Program in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

The objective of this program is to investigate the electro-optical properties of actively controlled graphene nanoribbon arrays with the goal to enable in-situ strain tunability of the bandgap for applications in infrared detectors covering an ultra-wide spectral range.

The intellectual merit is that the planned experiments provide new insights into the interplay between thermoelectric effects and built-in electric fields due to the Schottky barriers to the overall photocurrent generation. Furthermore, the controlled actuation of graphene nanoribbons with well defined edge chirality provides important insights into the relation between applied stress, band gap opening, and infrared absorption, for zigzag and armchair edges. The proposed device can detect terahertz radiation over a wavelength range with efficiencies similar to bolometers, but at much higher speed and with wavelength agility.

The broader impacts are that demonstration of the proposed device concept can enable a wide range of applications including high-speed communication in foggy environments, optical interconnects, terahertz detection, imaging, remote sensing, and spectroscopy. The planned educational initiatives provide training for students in science and engineering with a special focus on recruiting and mentoring students from under-represented minorities in partnership with the Women in Engineering Program and Advocates Network and the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering. The program will also work with the Center for Innovation in Science and Engineering Education at Stevens to extend this effort to K-12 outreach endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photodetectors are devices that are able to detect light by absorbing electromagnetic energy and converting it into an electrical current. Commercial photodetectors are typically made from semiconductor materials and are only able to detect light of a specific color (wavelength) range. With regard to silicon crystals, efficient light detection is only possible in the visible range that finds an application for example in digital photography. Our work in this project focused on growth, nanofabrication and characterization of photodetectors made from novel materials, in particular graphene ribbons with micrometer dimensions that are able to detect light over an ultra-wide spectral range from the visible to the long-wavelength infrared radiation regime with both high detection efficiency as well as high operation speed. Realizing broadband photodetection with only one material platform rather than a whole range of currently required different sensor technologies and incompatible materials has significant advances at the system level for novel detection schemes. Application wise, such monolithic graphene photodetectors will enable advances, for example, in high-speed communication in foggy environments as required in various civil and military applications, or for broadband infrared detection required for satellite based imaging, as well as for gas sensing and spectroscopy in general.

Some of our most important results include the large-area wafer-scale growth of high quality graphene and its integration into arrays of photodetector devices in such a way that it leads to a demonstrated 4-fold enhanced photocurrent generation (photoresponse) under infrared illumination compared to a standard device [Nature Scientific Reports 3, 2791 (2013)]. This was achieved by decoupling the photoactive graphene membrane from the underlying substrate material by experimentally realizing free-standing yet electrically contacted graphene microribbons utilizing a chemical etching process. The demonstrated 4-fold enhanced photoresponse enables detection of much weaker light signals, thereby significantly extending the range of utility of these photodetector devices.

Another key outcome regarding the intellectual merit of our work is the detailed study of the fundamental interaction of light and electrical carriers in these novel photodetectors. In particular, advances have been made to understand the complex interplay between several competing physical mechanisms that lead to the light-to-current conversion process (photocurrent generation mechanism) in graphene-based devices. As an outcome it was demonstrated that the photoresponse is dominated by the much faster photo-electric effect if the graphene ribbons were suspended in air. Otherwise, if the graphene ribbons were residing on a substrate within the photodetector device, the rather slow photo-thermoelectric effect was found to dominate the photoresponse. These findings are particularly important when high-speed operation is required and potentially enables higher cut-off frequency in the dynamic response of graphene microribbon photodetectors approaching several hundred GHz operation speed.

During the course of the project it became evident from recent literature that further progress in photodetector device performance can be achieved by utilizing layered structures between graphene and other two-dimensional materials such as the recently discovered novel semiconductor material called tungsten diselenide. Layered structures between monolayer graphene and monolayer tungsten diselenide are promising to significantly enhance device performance of future photodetectors.
